Award.AwardTitle: Pushing the Limits: Building Capacity to Enhance Public Understanding of Math and Science Through Rural Libraries

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is intended to develop a model for STEM education through local libraries. There are several unique features in this endeavor. The model is being aimed at rural libraries and adult residents that are geographically remote from typical venues such as museums, zoos, and science centers. According to the 2000 census, there are 50 million individuals in this designation and the size of the group is increasing and becoming more diverse. Efforts to impact diverse audiences who are economically disadvantaged will be part of the plan. In many rural locations there are few community venues, but libraries are often present. The American Library Association and the Association Rural and Small Libraries have begun the reinvention of these libraries so they can become more attuned to the communities in which they are apart. Thus, this project is an effort to find new ways of communicating STEM concepts to a reasonably large underserved group.

The design is to derive a "unit of knowledge enhancement" (some portion of Climate Change, for example) through a hybrid combination of book-club and scientific caf√© further augmented with videos and web materials. Another part of the design is to enhance the base STEM knowledge of library staff and to associate the knowledge unit with an individual who has the specific STEM topic knowledge for a specific unit. Considerable effort shall be expended in developing the models for staff knowledge enhancement with a progressive number of librarians in training from 8 to 20 to 135. To build the content library model, five units of knowledge will be devised and circulated to participating libraries. Evaluation of the project includes front end, formative and summative by the Goodman Research Group.

In addition to the "units of knowledge enhancement," the major results will be the model on how best to relate and educate citizens in rural environments and how to educate the library staff. Publications and presentations will be the major mechanism for elaboration of the results and encouragement for others to take up the model and adapt it for their own circumstances.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Pushing the Limits: Pushing the Limits: Building Capacity to Enhance Public Understanding of Math and Science Through Rural Libraries (PTL) is an NSF-funded program designed to build the capacity of rural libraries to provide programming enahncing public understanding of science and math. Libraries generally, but especially in small and rural communities, are often the social and cultural center of their communities. There is a growing movement by libraries to generally build and broaden their civic mission through public programs that foster community engagement and learning. Pushing the Limits builds on this movement, bringing informal STEM learning education (ISL)  into rural communities through libraries’ public programming. PTL was a partnership between Dartmouth College, Califa, the Association of Rural and Small Libraries, Oregon State University, and Dawson Media Group and was evaluated by the Goodman Research Group.

This project leveraged popular literature (fiction and historical non-fiction) and video as foundational materials for four community STEM-themed events,  facilitated by a librarian and local science partner to reach an underserved group in underserved areas: adult STEM learners in rural locations. Each event was organized around a brief discussion of the book, followed by the viewing (and discussion) of two short videos created specifically for the program. One video was an interview with the book’s author and the second was a human interest story – which focused on a given thematic idea from different angles. The four themes of PTL (with their related books) were “Pushing the Limits of Knowledge” (Jean Auel’s Earth’s Children), “Pushing the Limits of Nature” (T. C. Boyle’s When the Killing’s Done) “Pushing the Limits of Connection” (Erik Larson’s Thunderstruck), and “Pushing the Limits of Survival” (Clive Cussler’s Arctic Drift). The human interest video subjects were chosen with rural audiences in mind and based on information gathered in a national landscape study. PTL provided the videos, professional learning support (e.g., webinars and instructional videos), templates for marketing and promotional materials, and technical assistance.. Funding through mini-grants was also provided for the library professionals and their local science partners, the latter working with the librarians to co-facilitate this series of science café-style public discussions with adult patrons.  Ultimately, 94 libraries (20 in a pilot phase and an additional 74 in a second phase) took part in the project.

 

This project advances knowledge about ISL for adults who may self-identify as not interested in STEM topics. One challenge for engaging this population in STEM content is the perception that science is too difficult to understand, or not relevant. The content, approach, and setting of Pushing the Limits addresses these misconceptions, providing numerous points of entry for learning about STEM content and encouraging adults' development of lifelong skills and  science literacy. The project is guided by three key perspectives:  (1) community libraries are an ideal venue for reaching adult audiences who are not typically reached by traditional informal science education activities, and (2) multiple media platforms present a promising approach for engaging this audience, and (3) adult learners are likely to be engaged in STEM in the context of topics relevant to their interests. The project also advances our understanding of the inclinations of and potential impediments to librarians in these communities for acting as leaders in creating new community venues for ISL.
